instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message:
This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> had an short in the PP3V42 circuit and no green light. No waterdamage/visible damage. I fixed that and had to replace the SMC. Now it has a green /orange light again, battery indicator works, it turns on, has backlight and even chimes, but thats it. I cant enter boot menu (tried external keyboard too) and it also won´t boot from a known good installation drive. Now i am stuck. 
Thanks for any help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: Correct SMC from donor? Any indication how the SMC died, it does not "just" happen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: I guess it died from a surge on PP3V42. <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> had a hole in it and <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> was split in half. I replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> too to be sure... How can i know if the SMC is correct? i thought there are only the "980" and the "F211" SMCs...  Or has it to be from a board with the exact same 820-XXXX number?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: SMC has to be from the EXACT same board, so there is your issue I bet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: Ok, thank you. I did not know this... Im not sure but this can be the first time i had not the same donor to take the smc from. I try to take all parts from the exact same board if possible. I ordered two <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and let you know if the problem is still not solved...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: Yes. That was the issue... right SMC, SMC reset and new <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> (won´t run from battery) ant this one is fixed finally. i think that was the sixth SMC i put on this board... The first times i thought it was bad soldering... Incredible how lucky i was until now. I replaced quiet a lot SMCs and they worked - without me knowing this...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: Then there are probably a lot of boards with weird unexpected issues out there now. It will mess with thermal control, current/voltage sensing and even OSX detecting which kind of drivers to load.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message:
Ok... Thank you or the lesson. 99% i replaced SMCs on 3115 and 2936. They have different SMCs fortunately. Some 3437 too, but I took the SMCs (as all parts) from the exact same donor if possible and ordered new donor boards early to avoid any problems. This board was one of my first ones - or even the first one - i soldered on a SMC from a different donor and instantly experienced some issues. I had not the exact same donor lying around and could not find them easy to buy.
So some boards could be working with wrong SMCs while having some problems? And is it ok to reball the F211 SMCs (0.45mm balls) with the 980 (0.38mm balls) stancils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: So if I got that right (I never bought them) all the SMCs on Ebay, Ali, etc can not be used on MacBooks, right? Any idea if they can be used on other machines or are they just useless like the iPhone 7 Homebutton replacements?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message:
Depends, just random SMCs can not be bought and are most likely even just the unprogrammed chip.

If you find a pre-balled SMC which specifically mentions the board number you can buy those though. But they're a rare find.

Just get the right stencils, its a few bucks on ebay or ali

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Boot
threads.message: Ok, thank you. I stay with the reballing i think
